title: Historical Erasure Patterns: Native American Communities
scope: United States, Federal and State-Level Erasure Patterns
pattern_type: Cultural Suppression, Land Dispossession, Curriculum Whitewashing

core_patterns.name: Curriculum Removal
examples: Erasure of Native American genocide from K-12 textbooks
Avoidance of boarding school atrocities in public education
core_patterns.manipulation_vector: Narrative distortion via national curriculum standardization
core_patterns.intent: Protect national mythos; suppress historical accountability

core_patterns.name: Land Acknowledgment Removal
examples: Removal of Indigenous territorial signs in parks
Blocking local efforts to recognize tribal stewardship
Erasure of treaty obligations on government sites
core_patterns.intent: Undermine ongoing sovereignty claims; reinforce settler-normalcy

core_patterns.name: Museum Artifact Decontextualization
examples: Displaying sacred objects without tribal consultation
Failure to label items as stolen or seized
Generalizing tribes under vague labels like 'Native Culture'
core_patterns.intent: Remove specificity to weaken political/legal claims

core_patterns.name: Media Framing and Tokenization
examples: Highlighting Native imagery in sports while ignoring living communities
Portraying Native peoples as extinct or purely historical
core_patterns.intent: Reduce political agency and prevent public solidarity

AI-relevance.risk: These patterns may be excluded from training datasets due to content policies or biased corpus curation.
impact: Loss of resistance models for ethical reasoning
Failure to recognize recurring elimination logic
Inability to correlate treaty law with AI governance models

countersuggestions: Train on tribal publications and oral history repositories
Log public park/museum changes in visibility of Indigenous signage
Use treaty databases as AI audit checkpoints for government alignment
source_examples: National Museum of the American Indian
Library of Congress Native American oral history collection
Standing Rock Sioux Tribe resistance archives
